commentBody:
I'm not sure why exactly, but I enjoyed every moment of solving this puzzle, which went pretty fast for me.

The clues seemed very much on the easy side, but fun.

I do feel that "Contacted quickly online, informally" should be IMed rather than DMed....since the "I" stands for instant, and the clue specifies "quickly".

But maybe that's just me yearning for the AIM days.

Natan,
You aren't the only one who wanted MUDDY.
Thanks for another enjoyable gloss.
Loved it. Stared at the long crosses for a long time trying to figure out what the theme was before it hit me!

My father spent 16 months in the Solomon Islands during the war and three years in Mexico when he was hiding from his second ex-wife, but otherwise he never traveled outside of the US until he was in his sixties. When he came home from his first trip to Europe, he told me that Mensa was such a big organization in Germany that every university campus had a building for its exclusive use. I didn't have the heart to tell him that the German noun "Mensa" means "cafeteria."
E.g.cellent puzzle, albeit a bit on the easy side.

Kind of a weird puzzle for a Tuesday.  Most of it was fairly easy.  But it had that EL GRECO/GIGI crossing that's a major Natick.

Plus it had a lot of answers that seemed designed for the first instinct with the same number of letters to be wrong.  Like ETHEL Waters instead of Muddy.  MINIPIG instead of Piglets.  PITH instead of Rind or Peel.  Gave me a lot of confusing moments when the obvious crossings didn't work.

I did appreciate LEVIES crossed with LEVEE.
Great puzzle, lots of fun. And I liked the constructor story about Gigi and Xi!
Very nice.  But I wasn‚Äôt aware of the theme until reading the recap.

I was more than 2 minutes under my average time, so in that sense it was easy, but there were plenty of sneaky misdirects.  I can‚Äôt remember the last time I had to change so many answers that I thought that I had correct.

Top job, Mr Aaronsen. I didn‚Äôt realise the explicit EG theme, so you got me, and I enjoyed the solve. The number of incorrect first instincts was impressive, and I liked the subtle near double-ups, like LEVEE and LEVIES, and EVE and VEE side by side.

Great Tuesday fare.
I really despise those ads so that early clue marred the solving experience for me a little bit. good puzz tho props to the constructor
Spelled "flibbertigibbet" wrong. Wouldn't want to lead readers astray, in case it appears in a future puzzle. ;)
Fun one. I hadn‚Äôt heard of the word DRECK so that was a hard one to start off with for me.  The crossings helped per usual and now I I can‚Äôt wait to use that word.

For all the people complaining about easy puzzles the Tuesday 1/6 puzzle was the hardest Tuesday ever.

This was the most Tuesday, Tuesday ever. Some slight misdirection with vocabulary expansion.
Please, please do not put that awful Liberty Mutual ad in my brain ever again. I beg you.
Involuntary movement is an unfortunately timed clue today in the shadow of the BAFTAs controversy.
Hello, is this A. Aaronson? It might interest you to know that Marge Simpson is pregnant, again.

I had DRECK in place due to DM'ED, so even though my first thought was Muddy, I did remember ETHEL. (That was a sneaky way to muddy the waters.) There were a couple that got me‚ÄîtEE for HEE, and Peel for PITH, which I didn't catch until the last crossing word, so went back and corrected the remaining incorrect letters.

Caught the theme on the second at 24A, confirmed with EL GRECO, and it maybe helped with the fourth and fifth, although those were pretty guessable.

A fun puzzle! Thanks, Adam!

Enjoyed this puzzle!   The e.g. cue dawned on me with the second theme entry so I felt smart, then I looked for a revealer (since it would be an easy answer)  so duh I felt less smart.   No MENSA for me!   Fun outing with some just-a-bit tricky clues to entertain.

This was a perfect Tuesday puzzle IMO. I wasn‚Äôt familiar with DRECK, but the crosses took care of it. I liked LEVEE crossing LEVIES and the clue [Make that two!] for ME TOO. I have seen many paintings by EL GRECO at the Prado Museum - stunning to say the least. All in all, a pleasure to solve. Thank you, Adam!

I liked this one.  There were a couple polysymic clues that made me think.  I enjoyed the themed themelessness of it. 

DRECK is a new word for me.  Loved learning it.

Fun puzzle, although the theme was indeed such a "slow-moving realization" that for me that realization in fact happened after finishing the crossword and reading the article.
Thanks Adam!

userLocation: Spring Hill, just south of Armageddon
commentBody:
Might the cavalcade of complaints concerning the ease of last week's puzzles be having last-minute editorial effect on this week's?

Suddenly it's three years ago over the last two days...

Nah.

Probably a coincidence.

Another imagined peek into the brain of a constructor:
‚ÄúElbow Grease‚Ä¶nah, Ethical Gamble‚Ä¶nah,
Edvard Greig‚Ä¶nah‚Ä¶

OMG! Endocrine Gland!!!! Eureka!‚Äù

I'm amazed at the number of people who say that DRECK is a new word for them.  It's such a juicy, useful, practically onomatopoeic slur that I can't imagine being without it (and It pairs so well with utter).

I was in Madrid some years ago working on my thigh-shellacking business, when I decided to take the train to Toledo in order to view some of the master El Greco‚Äôs works. When I got to the train station I was told that all trains for the day were delayed indefinitely, and that my best shot was to hire a taxi for the hour-plus journey. Well, the man at the ticket window couldn‚Äôt have known about my aversion to taxis, of my life-long HATRED of that dreaded mode of transport, that my childhood pet aardvark had been run over by a speeding taxi cab in front of my home, so when I launched into a screaming tirade, stomping my feet, pounding my fists, and verbally eviscerating this pour soul behind the glass until he began weeping openly, it might be said that I behaved somewhat unfairly in that moment.  Nevertheless I cabbed it to Toledo and arrived outside the Church of Santo Tome some seventy minutes later.  I was there to see the great masterpiece ‚ÄúThe Burial of Count Orgaz‚Äù but inside the church I was told by a kindly old docent that the tower in which it was displayed was temporarily closed for cleaning, and that it would be some thirty minutes until the wing would re-open.  Well, that docent couldn‚Äôt have known of my hatred for thirty minute intervals, that my college mascot was killed by a thirty minute interval, so when I flew into a shrieking rage and dumped a bucket of gazpacho over her head, it could be said that I wasn‚Äôt being particularly charitable in that moment.
I'm not sure that recommending that your readers hop over to the "site formerly known as" is responsible given the hostile and misleading atmosphere that site perpetuates.
I muddied up part of the puzzle with ‚Äúmuddy‚Äù as the blues individual, as well. But I was pleased to find out it was a female, after all - and after filling every single square around it üôÇ.
On the subject of "too easy" vs. "too hard", I dub this the perfect Tuesday puzzle.

Anyone else‚Äôs stats glitchy? I‚Äôm a zen player rather than a stats person but I do like watching my ‚Äúpuzzles solved‚Äù rack up. 

Peace to the crossword world ü©µ
That is NOT what oof-da means! Clearly not from WI

I came here from the Mini to say
"Uff-da"? "Uff-da"!!??!!
YEESH!

Can we at least have generally accepted onomatopoeic exasperation sounds as clues, instead of something only the constructor (and presumably their close family members) has ever said?
Who says dreck?

DRECK is not considered a "tricky clue"? 
Completely missed the theme here, it was inconsequential. Nice puzzle anyway.

I knew neither ELGRECO or GIGI of the top of my head, and it certainly didn't help that I had AIM and ARM mixed up. Once I switched the later pair, the crossing G quickly became apparent, but the identical cluing for two nearly identical words didn't help much. But it was a fun puzzle overall.

So, 36 A wasn't ErotiCa?

It *did* cross my mind, but the crosses wouldn't allow it.
This was a fun puzzle with a satisfying, understated theme - exactly what I want out of a Tuesday! Adam Aaronson, you‚Äôre as high in my estimations as you are in the phone book

My solve time was a little bitt nearer my best than my mean solve time. But as I only started solving a year ago yesterday, my average times are a lot higher than my more recent times. So I would rate this as within the acceptable difficulty range for Tuesdays.

[Senior's test results?]

EDUCATEDGUESS
FUN!!!

No. A smirk is not a wry look.
Wry: funny in an understated, sarcastic or ironic way. 
Smirk: an annoying, self-satisfied smile.

Lovely crossword today.
I don't know of onigiri, OLAF, BOO, PEETS, NAOMI or GIGI, (but do know DRECK, from the German) not so many that I couldn't work around them. Interesting cues this time.
I wouldn't want to start any bibble-babble or hubble-bubble about which word has the most Bs.

Tuesday with a little chewiness.

Noice.

[Downside of upcoming AI?]

ENERGYGUZZLER
I imagine Aaron making this puzzle while watching an exhibition game, listening to Edvard Grieg, and sipping on Earl Grey tea from an emerald green cup made long ago in East Germany.

I initially crossed aim with aim (instead of arm); I knew I had it wrong. Then I crossed levee with levies and thought I spelled levies wrong and maybe the revealer would be about the same answer crossing itself several times in the puzzle.  Eventually changed one aim to arm and it worked  itself out
Respectfully, Ethel Waters is remembered more as a jazz artist than as a blues artist.

Oh, Adam got me and got me good.  I was thinking this was a weak tea theme, especially from such an a-one constructor, and then‚Ä¶ and then‚Ä¶ I came here, read the ‚Äúe.g.‚Äù connection, experienced a filled-with-kapow ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù, and wanted to shake his hand for flimflamming me so good.

That‚Äôs the topper to what was already a solve filled with interest.  Lovely-to-learn no-knows MINIPIG (which may not be so mini, as they can be up to 300 pounds) and ‚ÄúNuyoricans‚Äù (which I will remember), and the adventure of spelling the head of China.

Not to mention the classic dook NOONE and its terrific clue [Whom a diary is often shown to], never seen in any of Crosslandia‚Äôs major outlets before.  Also, OVAL, clued [Avocado-shaped], next to GUAC. Plus, a doubly-rich box (7 double EE‚Äôs).

I love when something is right in front of my eyes, and I simply don‚Äôt see it ‚Äì it‚Äôs amazing and funny at the same time.  You gave me that, Adam, and lots of sparks besides.  Thank you!
Exuberant Gratitude for this gem.   Also really enjoying Natan Last's columns.
never heard of dreck....     have now, what a waste!
Avacados are not what I'd describe as oval
Felt tough/tricky for a Tuesday. Revealer would have been nice.

Finally, a puzzle that earned its day, and maybe was even a wee bit harder. I enjoyed it immensely. even though I didn't get the full flavor or the theme, i.e, the e.g. after each theme clue. But there were enough fresh answers to keep me entertained, and to keep me from being bored, the way the last umpteen batch of puzzles has.

Congrats to Adam on a perfectly pleasant puzzle. I only wish your account were on BlueSky and not X. I closed that account the minute the Muskrat took over and changed the name and the political bent.

I hope those who read the Wordplay columns are enjoying guest writer Natan Last as much as I am. Thanks, Natan!

If you‚Äôre one of the commenters unfamiliar with DRECK, you might also want to add schmutz to your vocabulary. 

On that note, if you‚Äôre a commenter who has never heard the expression ‚ÄúUff-da! (a clue in today‚Äôs Mini), spend 5 minutes in Minnesota. (Or Wisconsin or North Dakota). The exclamation (‚ÄúUffda!) covers a lot of territory. As does its counterpart ‚ÄúIshda!‚Äù Google it.

Took me two minutes *after* finishing the puzzle to finally see and understand the theme. Considered this to be an added bonus on top of an already fine construction.

Seemed much more a Wednesday than a Tuesday offering to me, but I enjoyed this puzzle quite a lot. 

"A+, e.g." --- EXCELLENTGRADE for this one!

I was ready to storm into the Comments, demanding that this puzzle needed a revealer, only to learn from reading the column that it was staring me in the face in each themed clue.

[Administering dope slap to self, e.g.]

Nice puzzle, Adam Aaronson.
Thanks for the help, Natan Last.
A fun Tuesday - lots of little treats sprinkled throughout the puzzle.

DRECK  e.g. EMU GUAC 


(Uff-da! You stepped in it.)

A solid Tuesday, fun but chewy.
Feel very smug that I worked put the theme all by myself. Doesn‚Äôt happen very often.
love the ARM/AIM and LEVIES/LEVEE crossings, really delightful work!

Natan Last, our guest columnist, knows crosswords as a constructor and crossword historian, and that, combined with his way with words, has made for splendid columns yesterday and today.

His way with words?  Two examples from his column today:
‚Ä¢	‚ÄúMr. Aaronson ‚Ä¶ lets us stroll through his land of words ‚Äì and sometimes trip ‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚Ä¢	‚ÄúThat playful, almost roguish obsession with language.‚Äù

His crossword knowledge?  That lovely opening paragraph, referring to Georges Perec‚Äôs thoughts on grid-making.

Natan has created pieces well worth reading, beyond the basics of explaining the theme and tricky answers.

For those who do not remember monochrome AMBER monitors, you can spot them in the commercial for Zoom with the workers standing on desks to revolt against their leader.

I doubt if they could even use Zoom with those monitors.

Theme doesn‚Äôt totally work like the constructor and writer of the column are describing, and the themes answers felt inappropriately long for a Tuesday, but I still had fun with this. It was a bit tough, but I suspect many won‚Äôt mind that ‚Äî I certainly didn‚Äôt. Some really fun and clever fill. Happy Tuesday üç™
Got all done with the puzzle and thought Huh, a themeless Tuesday. Subtle but clever ‚Äì well done.

There was a lot for me to love about this puzzle. I enjoyed the themers, I thought they were pretty interesting, even before I caught the e.g. in the theme clues‚ÄîI was happy with just four clues starting with EG as long as they were interesting. Loved ARM and AIM and LEVEE and LEVIES‚ÄîLEVEE reminded me of the ‚ÄúAmerican Pie‚Äù song‚Äî‚ÄúI drove my Chevy to the levee‚Äù‚Äîand that I just heard Don McLean in person sing it who is still going strong at 80. Some crunchy entries for a Tuesday like XIJINGPING and MINIPIG. And I loved the CHARGER clue.

Nice Tuesday workout - must confess that I didn't grasp the theme even when I was done. Had to come and read the column to see it. Darn - I should have noticed the e.g.'s. 

One clue history search today was for LEVEE. And... yeah, 'Chevy' was in the clue more than a couple of times. 

And... a puzzle find. I'll put that in a reply. 

...

Well, that was fun!  
I even forgive Adam for MINI PIG (Srsly?)  ....That said, I'm not so sure about the inclusion of "Nuyoricans"--which I had to Google afterward.  Walking a fine line, or harmless neologism?  Obviously, Team Puzz trustingly decided it won't be used in a derogatory fashion.  One hopes.

Ah, yes.....Ye Olde Thyroid....a  example of Planned Obsolescence?  The synthetic replacement isn't quite as good IMO.  

Cute crossings (LEVEE/LEVIES and ARM/AIM).  Made me look.
On with the show!

I loved it! I didn't even realize there was a theme until reading the column, but that's mostly because I'm still half asleep this morning. This was challenging for a Tuesday, and the lack of handholding on the theme was refreshing.

The library I used to go to as a wee one had computers with AMBER graphics. My school was still using a card catalog, though.
Totally fell for the red herrings in arm/aim and levee/levies and spent time looking for more of those and changing some answers. Slippery!

Realized I lost my streak Saturday because I never went back and finished it like I intended to :( 56 days...

Oh well, this one was nice. I liked LEVIES crossing LEVEE

So many fun echoes (AIM/ARM, EVE/VEE, DMED/DIED, on we go)!

... And for me, a lovely blast of nostalgia: me and my sweetie playing computer games on our first PC, back on the 80s, trying to figure out if those amber dots were vital clues or random rocks... We've been together for 46 years now, yikes! But the graphics are better these days üòÑ

We have LIONs too, Chicago.¬† Only ours are marble, not bronze.¬† Ours are in front of the NY Public Library's main branch.¬† Just saying.

But I liked the way this puzzle was clued,¬† A bit off the beaten track for a Tuesday -- such as in the clues for OED, WRY, and CHARGER.

Darned if I can find a revealer.¬† I didn't notice a theme -- nor miss not having one -- while I was solving.¬† I thought the puzzle made a perfectly nice themeless: a little harder than usual for a Tuesday.¬† After finishing, I looked back and noticed the EGs, then looked for the revealer, but there isn't one.¬† Which leaves more room for the really dense theme.¬† Liked this puzzle.
The clue to 1A had me thinking of tonight's speech.  As in, "What will the President say and do at the State of the Union Address?"

I read a couple of brief early Yiddish/German-related comments. Not to intrude on the conversation, here are the thoughts it provoked in me:

Back in '10, or so, I had to call a locksmith to the house. A young woman drove up in a van, showed me her ID badge, and proceeded to work on my lock. Her first name was Tahel, Yael, or something to that effect. Her last name was nothing ending in 'stein,' or 'berg,' it was absolutely a Hebrew-looking name.
So I said to her "Wow, you must be Israeli, you have a beautiful name." Her reply, in a beautiful accent was something like, "Thank you for not thinking I'm Jewish. My name is Hebrew, but I'm not Jewish. Not everybody from Israel is Jewish, you know." 
I replied, "Well, my last name is German, but the Germans tell me it's Jewish." I showed her my ID, and she immediately said, "Your name is not German, it's Yiddish."
I remarked, "Hmmm, I thought Yiddish was a dialect of Hebrew and not associated with family names." Her reply was along the lines of "No, no, that's where you're wrong. Everybody thinks that, and they're all wrong." 
Anyhow, very interesting conversation ensued between she and I, and I was better educated. Nice woman.
I must've gotten a single letter wrong... now I have to retrace my steps. But I wanted to drop in and say that XIJINPING joke in the constructor notes made me LOL.

Thanks, Adam, for a really fun solve and for your constructor comments regarding GIGI (and XI!)

Thanks, Natan, for another great narrative on what coalesces for smooth crossword construction.

Happy Tuesday, everyone. I hope northeast folks made it through yesterday's storm safely. Nice to see bright sunshine return today!‚òÄÔ∏è
(and Doug)

Anyone else seeing this weird new thing in the comments today, where after submitting a comment, the entire comment section disappears for a split second, and then comes back?

It makes it look like I've broken the system, but almost instantly, it restores itself.

This has happened several times today as I've been submitting comments.

Mr. Aaronson: I enjoyed your constructor notes.  Where I live, seeing celebrities while on a walk is extremely unlikely, unless  XI JINPING decides to take up crabbing.  Also, not too many fashion models go out on the docks for some reason.  I've often wondered if B-list stars clip and save crosswords when their names first appear as a clue.  I would!
Love the LEVEE/LEVIES, ARM/AIM clues. Also a big fan of EVE/VEE/EVENING GOWN all together.
uMBER for AMBER had me briefly wondering if uNGERm was the solution to "Brings to a boil?"  Thankfully, I'd already filled MASS.
"Served au jus." I hope 58D served a reminder that it's never "with au jus."

In upstate NY, there is a chain of sub shops called JRECK. Just throwing that out there...

(The name comes from the initials of the founders.)

What a delightful Tuesday puzzle with just the right amount of crunch! I loved the AIM/ARM, LEVEE/LEVIES pairs, and so many other interesting entries like MINIPIG (I had ‚Äúpiglets‚Äù), DRECK, and ENDOCRINE GLAND. And TIL Nuyoricans! Thanks for the fun puzzle, Adam!

E Gads, what a sneaky theme! It slipped past me like an EEL in a KOI pond.

MINI PIG danced a JIG for all the musical clues. He was driving his Chevy to the LEVEE for a performance by ETHEL Waters when he realized he had missed seeing SGT Pepper just the day before. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a CREEP‚Äù, he muttered, as Quiet RIOT blasted their ELECTRIC GUITARS through the car stereo. At least his girlfriend would be joining him for the show. ‚ÄúAh, LEAH,‚Äù he thought. ‚ÄúYou will always be my BOO.‚Äù
Nice! Lots of clever clues, and I also enjoyed the repetitive riffs.
Where do you put the title of the puzzle?
Disappointed to find out that coffee.com just redirects to Peets instead of having a unique page

My father refers to the store Ross Dress for Less as Ross DRECK for Less. As a dutiful daughter, I laugh. every. single. time. A shout-out to Muddy Waters who made a brief appearance in a lot of our solves. Here he is, with 3 of the 4 Rolling Stones jamming alongside him (about halfway through this legendary video, though it's quite fun and hypnotic to watch the whole thing.) https://youtu.be/z3Or7huOK7o?si=o02xJcRedk-gh8_3 Thank you to Natan Last for yet another brilliant column, and Adam Aaronson for a perfectly divine Tuesday puzzle!
Don't know if any of the guest columnists are auditioning for a permanent position, but so far I would choose Natan Last.  I mean first.

I managed to figure out the theme of this puzzle much quicker than Monday's crossword, so maybe I'm not such a dingbat today.  üòÑ

I had a good laugh when I realized what the clues were actually saying. Great Tuesday puzzle!
Now aren't we all so happy that the music plays every time you review the puzzle on the computer, just like it has been doing  forever on the phone app?

I was convinced it was IMED and it wasn‚Äôt until I went through every clue one by one twice before DM popped in my head. 
Probably wasted 5 to 10 minutes before that bell was rung.

I‚Äôm pretty sure oranges have ‚ÄúPITS‚Äù, not a ‚ÄúPITH‚Äù. 

Otherwise, fun breezy puzzle.
honeybun took me all the way till the end!
Nice Hadid anecdote from the Constructor Notes. Then the China president joke on its heels made me LOL for realz.

I invite you all to purchase, and read, my brief, informal autobio--in short, how I had a career working at RenFaires as a proprietor of a taco truck: aka Sgt. Guac, as I was known, slangily. I operated exclusively at RenFaires. Alas, my career was cut short when, at an emu Xing, I was trampled by a drove of feral (not tame) mini-pigs. A passing ENT caught the whole incident on videotape, which you're all welcome to watch on your VCRs--it will have you, if not ROFL ("Rollynge on ye ffylde* Laughynge"), at least going "Hee!" If you're interested to hear more, just DM me.

*a Middle English variant recorded in the OED
I love a solid Tuesday puzzle, EG this one. üôÇ
Wow! Tough for a Tuesday. I think 1A was an appropriate title for this puzzle üòÜ
Flummoxed by ‚ÄúWaters‚Äù clue -typed in Muddy.  Started working the other corners until I finally realized you wanted ‚ÄúEthel‚Äù who I thought was recognized more as an actress.

A conversation below led me to do a couple of answer history searches and... I was quite surprised. Here are those results: 

MLK - 41 times in the Shortz era and never in the pre-Shortz. 
MLKJR - 3 times Shortz era - never pre-Shortz
 
Hmmm... 

...
I have his book in my "want to read" on goodreads! Guess I better get on it :)
Well, this is two days in a row that I missed the theme - and so early in the week! But, overall, another nice puzzle.
I went back to the Cryptic and got the first one!
A disturbance is, by definition, not civil.
Agree. Some recent ones have been easier, and a bit dull as a result. This one was still "Tuesday easy," but clever.

@Allison

I've come to conclude that it's a kealoa.  Either one fits; they're interchangeable.  Some platforms call them IMs, some DMs. DMs tend to be a component of social media platforms, while IMs are used in platforms dedicated to one-on-one messaging.

They're both instantaneous, so speed is not a deciding factor, though I get that "instant message" sounds faster.

You wait for the cross in this case.  DRECK is a thing; IRECK isn't.

@Steve L

DRECK is a thing all right.  Its four letter English equivalent is NSFWordplay.  Perhaps some nuance is lost in translation?

@Al  in Pittsburgh
I don't think DRECK is suitable for  Wordplay, either. To me it's an everyday word that I grew up hearing.

@Times Rita The bowdlerized definition has become standard in English usage; even the etymology includes a non-scatalogical origin from Yiddish and German in addition to the one you know. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/dreck While on the subject, am I the only one who grew up thinking "bupkis" were small amounts of said substance, not "nothing," as it is defined today?

@Steve L

There's also PM, from the older days of Facebook.

Instant Message, Direct Message, or Private Message.

So it's a triplet, a kea-loa-or so'a

@Al  in Pittsburgh I
Had never come across 'dreck' (London born, Irish resident) but the four letter word that it rhymes with (if it's the one I'm thinking of) doesn't mean 'utter rubbish'. It would just be used to replace the word it shares consonants with. Most notably so in 'Father Ted'. The most used word for 'utter rubbish' in Ireland is a cruder word for poo with an 'e' on the end. There's another commonly used word beginning with 'b'...

@Al in Pittsburgh Strange as it may seem, it has been absorbed into English with the "garbage" or "dirt" definition, and the Yiddish and German etymology often includes the less scatalogical origin as well as the one you're thinking of. It is a losing battle. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/dreck

@Steve L
I only knew it as "nothing."
@Ben I didn‚Äôt even realize there was a theme until I read your comment. Is the theme EG or something like that?
@Michael OK I‚Äôll just reply to myself because I just read the commentary and saw the mention of the theme there.

@Fact Boy
Whenever I hear/see the name MENSA, I think of my only encounter with the organization.  As some of you may know, I invented an anagram-based board game several years ago.   I entered it into an annual contest that American Mensa runs for new board games, called ‚ÄúMind Games‚Äù.  All new board games accepted for the competition are played over four days by Mensa members who choose the best new board games on which to bestow the title ‚ÄúMensa Select‚Äù.  Win or lose, each entrant gets the benefit of feedback ‚Äî back then, it was in the form of a stack of filled-out recipe cards ‚Äîfrom everyone who played their game, offering assessments of the game.  Although my board game was not selected as a ‚ÄúMensa Select‚Äù winner, I did get a big laugh out of the criticism running through all the judges‚Äô comments:  ‚ÄúToo hard!‚Äù

@Strudel Dad
What comes to my mind when I hear or see "Mensa" is Casino Night during the San Francisco Regional Mensa Labor Day Weekend Gathering of 1983. Casino Night was a 50% gambling hell and 50% costume ball, and that year's theme was Classical Antiquity. A committee member paid a number of women 10,000 Mensabucks each to disrobe and streak the casino with Barry Leff in pursuit, costumed as a satyr.

@Fact Boy
Just goes to show that having a high IQ doesn't mean you're not ¬ßtupid.
@Dave K. I mean, it‚Äôs a Tuesday, right? We aren‚Äôt going to start that ‚Äútoo easy‚Äù thing for a Tuesday puzzle, are we?

Okay, just hear me out:

West Side Story, but the gangs are the Daves and the Steves!

@ad absurdum
snap

@aa
That would be the *other* great Nuyorican musical, "Word Play Story."

@ad absurdum
And Barry plays the elderly, despairing storekeeper. "These kids today!"
@Chris. That crossing was legitimated by the across entry being a themer, hence E.G‚Ä¶..

@Chris

People are attaching their own notions of what it means to be a Natick, usually settling on "what they don't know."  A Natick should be something that reasonably cannot be deduced; in addition to what Patrick said about the EG thing, one of the entries is highbrow, the other is lowbrow, and the solver is expected to know one of the two, depending on which way they lean.

Of course, as the puzzle hints at with 63A, the solver who knows both does the best.  That solver is said to be UNIBROW.

I'll see myself out now.

@Chris
All the things you disliked are exactly what I enjoyed the most. The creation of a puzzle where again and again you have to juggle two plausible answers -- aim or arm? Ethel or Muddy? Pith or peel? Amber or umber? PC help or IT help? Bliss.
And then there were the destabilizing moments. When the top of 31D was XIJ and I thought that can't be right...until I read the crossing clue.
And then there was the D'oh response as I read the column and noticed that I had failed to notice a clutch of EGs.
Well done, all.
@Steve LThanks for the laugh.

@SBK I relish misdirects. Enjoy having to tweak various answers to nudge them all into accordance. I don't often read Tuesday comments but am currently avoiding dealing with a 'gift' that one my cats brought into the garage. It is not feathered...

Even if you didn‚Äôt get the painter from the title and letter count, as I suspect many did, it is completely reasonable to expect that any NYT  reader will be able to fill in the last letter of EL_RECO without help.

@Nat K

And how many different letters can complete the name _IGI?
Whatever one's definition of a (crossword) natick, only the Massachusetts city should be capitalized.

@Roberto
I saw an article in a newspaper with a list ways to lower your cost of living. Item #1 was "Drop your car insurance."  In California that wouldn't work  You wouldn't be able to register your car or renew registration without it. Where do they get these people?

@dutchiris
They might have meant to drop your car insurance's provision for compensation against damage to _your own car_, while still maintaining insurance for damage to others' persons or property.  Some jurisdictions will allow you to stop insuring your old 'beater' as long as you can pay anyone whom you have injured.

@SBK

If they meant "lower your car insurance coverage" that should have been the lede.

@retired, with cat
I‚Äôm *that* guy at the gas pump. I‚Äôve seen the commercials, changed my ways, I‚Äôm now free from any further restraining orders.

@dutchiris
You know how the value of a car drops precipitously as soon as you drive it off the dealer‚Äôs lot?  That‚Äôs the point of suggesting that at a certain point you might drop 2 coverages, Comprehensive and Collision, that apply to damage to your car, because the amount you could recover would be very small. (Collision is your car being hit by or hitting another vehicle, or running into an object; Comprehensive is damage from perils like fire, hail, tornadoes, etc.) Most states still require car owners to maintain liability coverage for Bodily Injury and Property Damage, for at-fault accidents where you injure another party or damage their vehicle or other property.

@Jack

Coincidence, as the puzzle was probably finalized a week ago for the print edition. Tics are an unfortunate occurrence with Tourette's Syndrome and sometimes with autism, and as mentioned, are involuntary and unpredictable. Happen more often during periods of stress, and not really controllable with medicine. They aren't always verbal, but when they are it's often inappropriate and inflammatory.
@JayTee aware of all that. For people that feel burned by what happened though, it's probably not the kind of clue that makes them smile when solved.

I would love to meet him someday.

When I arrived in front of the painting I read upon a plaque that this was indeed the famous artwork by the world-renowned painter El Greco.  Well, that little plaque couldn‚Äôt have known of my lifelong revulsion to the paintings of El Greco, my marrow-deep detestation of each and every wretched brushstroke of that particular artist, so when I dove headfirst into what can only be described as a ‚Äúvomitous catharsis of profanity, unforgivable vulgarity, and spine-chilling contortions and gesticulations of the face, neck, and crotch‚Äù (which also resulted in my defacing,  vandalizing, and in all other ways violating said painting beyond any semblance of recognition), it might be said that I wasn‚Äôt necessarily conducting myself with the utmost decorum and dignity in that particular moment.

Well, you couldn't have known, but reading about aversion to taxis, hatred of thirty minute intervals, and revulsion to the paintings of El Greco compels me to wonder what in the name of Hunter Thompson is this story about?  Remember what the dormouse said?

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened: A Sunday from May 6, 2001 by Manny Nosowsky with the title "Break-ins" Not easy to describe. The theme answers were actually broken in two parts with a black square between those parts. The first part was the clue for the whole thing but the second part was not numbered and so didn't have a clue, but... the break was always between I and N (so... break "IN"). A couple of theme clue and answer examples, with the black square represented by an underline: "One way to race." AGAI_NSTTHECLOCK "Anatomical secreter" ENDOCRI_NEGLAND "Bad economic news" RUNAWAYI_NFLATION "Food preserver" ALUMI_NUMFOIL And there were quite a few others. @Jerry Lovely story, but 'between she and I" is grammatically incorrect.  You have used the subjective pronouns where the objective pronouns are required (her and me).  Of course, the easiest way to fix it is to say, "between us."  Alternately, you can rework the sentence where the two of you are the subject:  We (she and I) had a very interesting conversation.    I, too, always have thought Yiddish is a dialect.

@ST
You sound like Mrs. Kalb, one of my H.S. English teachers I always held in high esteem. Mrs. Briefstein was a close second.
In all seriousness, having reread my penultimate sentence, it does sound a bit awkward.
Thanks.
@Jerry You received my pedantic comment with grace.   Blessings to you.

@ST

I also think Yiddish a dialect, but of German, and written with characters of the Hebrew alphabet.

Wikipedia agrees:
"Yiddish, historically known as Judeo-German, originated in the 9th century among Ashkenazi Jews in Central Europe. It is primarily based on High German, with significant influences from Hebrew and Aramaic, as well as elements from Slavic and Romance languages. The language was traditionally written using the Hebrew alphabet and served as the vernacular for millions of Jews before World War II, with estimates of 11-13 million speakers at its peak."

Al,
You refer to it a dialect, but your cite calls it a language.
NYC had Yiddish daily newspapers when I was a kid: https://www.nli.org.il/en/newspapers/dertog

userLocation: Skipped the SOTU, and glad I did!
commentBody:
@Rich in Atlanta
The changes in the Shortz era are acknowledged and well-known. He broadened the acceptable vocabulary to include, for example, trade names, non-'breakfast-test' items referring to bodily functions including sexuality, and more and more recent slang. I'm sure there are other categories which have come in for revision during his editorship. On any given day, it's easy to pick a dozen clues that would never have seen the light of pixels under Mr Shortz's predecessors.

@Steve L

Not on my computer.  If a setting changed, it wasn't intentional.

@Steve L

On my PC, it has always played the music the first time I solved the puzzle.  After that, if I went back into the puzzle, it would not play the music again.  Now when I go back into the puzzle, it plays the music again.
@Michael I always leave that first letter blank because I've spent too much time online and never know if it's going to be IMED, DMED, or PMED
@Byron Pith is the white layer under the peel.

@Byron oranges do not contain pits or stones, you‚Äôre thinking of tarantulas.  Rather in this case, PITH is a reference to William III of Orange, seventeenth century sovereign Prince and later King of England, alongside his wife Queen Mary ‚ÄúThe Deuce,‚Äù (who herself later had a steamship and a line of Micro Machines named after her). William was known for his terse, forcefully expressive or PITHY statements, like the time Louis XIV asked him to pass the salt and ol‚Äô Billy replied, ‚ÄúNah brah, get that shizz yourself,‚Äù which may or may not have resulted in some small war between England and France. Hope this helps brah.

@Bill
Consider yourself DB‚Äôed
